-_0Aj5TC7ku9hDTGTifSPQ.text: This place serves some pretty authentic cold soba at a reasonable place. Tempura was well made and tasty. Would have been better if the tempura sauce comes with grated radish. Do note that the other set meals on the menu appear to be on the pricier side, and you do have to pay to top up for the hot pot soups.

photos.caption: Photo of Tomi Sushi - Singapore, Singapore

WhPzZ2BzkngKwEUYCrZhkw.text: I've been going to Tomi for a few years and the standard has been pretty consistent. Quality sushi and sashimi served at solid prices. Service is polite and generally fast. Decor isn't anything fancy; I wouldn't recommend this as a date place. The lunch specials are pretty worth it. $25 for a sashimi lunch set (sasimi, rice, pickles, soup and appetizer, fruit and salad) and $28 for a chirashi don set (chirashi don, soup, salad, fruit and chawanmushi). I've ordered a la carte (from the regular and monthly specials menu). It was very good but it added up quickly! Tomi renovated a few months ago and while the prices and quality for the lunch specials haven't changed, the portions have gotten a tad smaller! I guess something had to give. A new addition with the renovation: they now sell bottles of sake to go, at a slightly cheaper price than dining-in!

photos.caption: Photo of Tomi Sushi - Singapore, Singapore. lunch menu page 2
Photo of Tomi Sushi - Singapore, Singapore. lunch menu page 1
Photo of Tomi Sushi - Singapore, Singapore. closeup of sashimi

VIOpjyKZ1K4e_uzGJJZt1g.text: Quality sushi and sashimi served at this family-friendly restaurant. They're serious about the quality of the food and it shows. Prices can run up a little if you order a la carte but you get what you pay for - the freshest cuts for a reasonable price.I had the lunch set of the day, which came with salad, chawanmushi, 8 pieces of nigiri sushi, about 5 pieces of anago (salt water eel) tempura, miso soup, and coffee jelly. At $28++ or $33 net, I'd say this was a steal.

photos.caption: Photo of Tomi Sushi - Singapore, Singapore. Today's daily lunch set

xA4GwpURrE14-du07Qkfpw.text: A warning late last year that tsukiji fish market will be closed for about a week at the beginning of 2015 resulted in me having to curtail my japanese cravings till after.obviously, tomi was not a bad option after one week of fasting.the daily lunch set on display, outside the shop, attracted me like bees to honey and the daily lunch set it had to be!for those who can't decide, their numerous sets, many seasonal specials plus ala carte options, will leave you even more undecided!but thankfully their helpful photo menu does seduce you, with their visual appeal, to arrive at a quicker decision.my strategy has always been to stick to any particular specials or sets that they might be promoting. these are normally the freshest and also most bang for the buck.for sushi fans, the rice here may be more generous than you are used to but it is only because they use Niigata KOSHIHIKARI rice, the best brand in Japan, and wants you to have more of a good thing!:)as for their special purpose soy sauce, i can't really taste the subtle difference, quite possibly one being saltier than the other?tomi invaded SG back in 2010 with much fanfare for it's flagship parco outlet.back then my taste buds were not as refined and tomi was sort of a revelation.but since then the tsunami of really good sushi joints have left tomi@parco in it's trail of destruction, which eventually led to it's closure.i'm glad this tomi has sprouted and is so near to me.for those days that i just need my fish to be fresh and tea to be hot, i come to tomi.

photos.caption: Photo of Tomi Sushi - Singapore, Singapore. Suruten chirashi don, daily lunch set, $28++.
Photo of Tomi Sushi - Singapore, Singapore. View of the variety of seafood from the sushi counter.
Photo of Tomi Sushi - Singapore, Singapore. Niigata's specially selected local fish from the sea of japan.

_X8Ydsjrw2YyRTJX1S4WQQ.text: Nice Japanese restaurant in Novena Square. Quite crowded when we got there. The sashimi was quite fresh and the tempura was crispy and delicious. The Kaisen don was also good. The beef was also good. Quite authentic Japanese food.

photos.caption: Photo of Tomi Sushi - Singapore, Singapore. The Kaisen don set meal.

-jOM8LGhoOXgcRc8k5jBwQ.text: Quality Japanese food at reasonable prices that are highly that your sushi tei but lower than your tatsuya. There are monthly and seasonal menus to keep your taste buds excited each visit. Friday night was packed and the order took a while to arrive. A couple of mistakes in the order were made but luckily quickly rectified. No point making a second order on the busy night because the food will take forever to arrive and likely after you are done with four first round of ordering. Service was trying when there's a crowd but still acceptable.

photos.caption: Photo of Tomi Sushi - Singapore, Singapore. Yosen nabe and negitoro don (back)

LOpRnhjfhDSf49OzOSrthw.text: I have been wanting to try Tomi Sushi for the longest time and finally got the chance to do so. After reading reviews that the sushi is better than the other items, I decided to go for the daily lunch special ($30++) instead of the Nigiri Sakura set. The daily lunch special includes deep fried salmon cheeks in sauce, sushi, chawanmushi, miso soup, salad and fruits. I find the sushi is ok, it is better than the usual sushi chain, but not as good as expected. I guess I should have tempered my expectations a bit. The fish is fresh but the uni could be better. The salmon cheek pieces were drenched in the sauce that it was too salty sweet for my taste and there were so many bones and scales to make it enjoyable. Pork cheek it is not. My bad for equating cheeks to tender morsels of meat. The chawanmushi was a nice surprise. No bubbles in it. It was silky smooth and slid down easily. The miso soup was average. The salad had too much dressing in it. I should have ask for all sauces and dressing to be on the side. Fruit dish was the nondescript slice of watermelon and grapes. The service was ok, they only went round topping hot tea when the room was packed which was about a quarter past 12. I like the bright and airy dining room which makes it a pleasant dining experience. There is another section which is the sushi counter where you can watch the sushi chefs slice and dice and make your sushi in front of you.

photos.caption: Photo of Tomi Sushi - Singapore, Singapore
Photo of Tomi Sushi - Singapore, Singapore. Sauces
Photo of Tomi Sushi - Singapore, Singapore

Brol22NZbN9kr1fG5DBA3w.text: It is almost fast food Japanese. For the price, I have had better food and service in Singapore.

Z9W1j7cR_7X5FeumhGKe7A.text: This place did not let down my tastebuds addiction to sashimi and my ever increasing draw to any Japanese seafood. I had one of the bento box type dishes with sashimi, miso, rice and some white fish. The price for decent Japanese can be expensive in Singapore with a lack of quality. However I assume this place is actually run by Japanese that want to hold up there reputation for fresh food. Lovely fresh sashimi and sushi rolls, good price. Recommended for locals of Novena & Newton.

VwHLXY2jOk9ewCNfoyc8BQ.text: Really good quality sushi made with care and value for money. The lunch sets are a bargain - although Ichiban Boshi around the corner attracts the queue. I'd rather pay a bit more for the better quality sashimi and sushi here. The lunch chirashi bowl is really worth the money. Had the unajyu set really and it's the best value for unagi I've had in singapore. It's $50 but the substantial chunk of eel is beautifully grilled, tender and the sauce is not sweet and full of umami.

photos.caption: Photo of Tomi Sushi - Singapore, Singapore. Nigiri Sakura
Photo of Tomi Sushi - Singapore, Singapore. Steak wafu gozen promotion - super value for money.
Photo of Tomi Sushi - Singapore, Singapore. Wakatori karaage

osHZ4o5htrI6LiShIR1cqQ.text: I often walk past this place on the way to the gym but this is my first time trying it. The place always looks very empty and I always had the impression that it would be very ex. Nevetheless, my review is that this is really high-quality Jap food. Unfortunately, my Jap friends do not know about this place although the franchise apparently came from Japan.We opted for the sets - tempura and cord fish. It's quite a small serving though. For the cord fish, you also get salad and sashimi. Round it up with pickles, miso soup and fruits make for a delightful meal. The place is clean and brightly lit. The staff are friendly.

H611nRNGLuQ8K15wUHqWFQ.text: My fave sushi joint for an affordable but filling lunch set at good quality. They fly in their fish supply from Tokyo at least once a week and all the rice is from Niigata. Always a good sign when the sushi and sashimi soy sauces are different (one is lighter and more fragrant, the other saltier and stronger flavored). Service is good and the owner is Japanese, though the counter chefs appear to be mainly Chinese with one Japanese (head?) chef. Always packed at lunch so avoid peak hours if possible.

ExSFAgjnRPJ3siQR-o9Dlw.text: Tomi Sushi has in the recent month opened up another outlet at Velocity (Novena Square), tucked at a corner. This place comes highly recommended by many and being a japanese food lover, I decided to check it out.This place prides themselves for bring the best japanese from Niigata and is very particular about the rice and soy sauce used.  The restaurant caters to people of different needs. It is suitable for families and private party too. I have checked out the place during lunch and decided to try out their lunch sets. I ordered their salmondon ($15).  The sets are value for money and if you are in the mood for some hot soba, you can top up and change the miso soup.  They do have limited and seasonal items that you can order too.  If you are in the mood for ala carte, do prepare to pay a bit more as it can get rather pricey.

photos.caption: Photo of Tomi Sushi - Singapore, Singapore. Salmondon

7MUqPAWbKdSgFyRy8xujfw.text: One of a few authentic Japanese sushi stores in Singapore. Price is reasonable given its good food quality.

Xx5dR2RRaiBf6pe31O41Ag.text: This is THE sushi place according to my father, who had excitedly rushed us down for lunch on a Sunday to bring us to his favourite local Japanese restaurant for the first time. Claiming that he never eats sushi in Singapore from any other restaurant, my sushi-loving siblings were more than eager to go but...there were a few hiccups and we were late. We arrived at 2pm on the dot, just as they were closing the kitchen. After much negotiation with the waitress, she let us in on the condition that we finish our food by 2.30. However, we were informed that the kitchen does not serve hot food anymore, and as I'm not a huge fan of sashimi and sushi, we were somewhat bummed. A minute later, this was fixed by my father talking to the chef so I'd say, 2 thumbs up for service excellence. The food was excellent, especially the sushi sets. I can't comment on sashimi that I don't eat but the sushi sets at lunch were worth the price, although the other dishes such as tempura and maguro katsu pale in comparison. If you do visit, you're better off ordering a pure sushi set because I have to concur with my dad but I don't think the other dishes were quite as worth the while. Do arrive on time though because rushing a meal is never good for digestion.

FzJopfu4AmneMLGWR1gQuQ.text: We came across this sushi bar while looking for another one, it was getting late and we had our hearts set on some good sushi and good sushi we got.  The service and sushi were top notch, and they had anything you would possibly want between sushi and grilled fish.  The prices are a bit high, but I think it still represents good value and I will stop here again when back in Singapore.

qIUBj37tVTZTZ2T92_pXTQ.text: Tomi Sushi is a very solid option in Novena which delivers some very good sushi at a reasonable price.  Tomi sushi is a small chain that hails from Niigata, which is famous for its rice and sake.  They are definitely proud of both at Tomi, and also pay attention to many details, such as using a different soy sauce for sushi versus sashimi.  I dropped by for a late lunch, and found myself overwhelmed with many choices in terms of lunch sets.  I picked the reasonably priced Sakura Nigiri set, which included 8 pieces of sushi, a small salad, chawanmushi, chicken kara-age, miso soup, and fruit - all for $28. The sushi was excellent, and as the wasabi is already in the nigiri, there is no additional wasabi. The style is definitely very close to what you will eat in Tokyo, and the sushi was very good.  The rice was good, but the texture was different from what I usually expect - it was less firm here, but still very good. The sake list focuses on selections from Niigata, which is one of my favorite regions, and the prices were reasonable.  I'll definitely be coming back, as they are having some unagi specials including Hitsumabushi!  Very highly recommended  for a more traditional, authentic taste without blowing the bank.
